section.title: Linear Operations
section.p:
Let \R denote the set of real numbers. The (Cartesian) planeCartesian Plane
is the set \R^2 = \{(a,b)\colon a,b\in \R\} of ordered pairs of real numbers.

The sumsum in \R^2
(a,b)+(c,d) of two ordered pairs (a,b) and (c,d) is defined by (a,b)+(c,d) = (a+c,b+d). The scalar multiplescalar multiple \alpha(a,b) of the real number \alpha times the ordered pair (a,b) is defined by \alpha(a,b) = (\alpha a,\alpha b). The dot productdot product (a,b)\cdot (c,d) of two ordered pairs (a,b) and (c,d) is defined by (a,b)\cdot (c,d) = ac+bd.

An ordered pair is sometimes called a point in \R^2, and sometimes called a vector, depending on the nature of the object represented by (a,b). In drawings, a point is a dot, and a vector is an arrow. For a dot (a,b), we use a capital letter, say P, to denote the point P=(a,b). An arrow is a directed line segment that begins at some point Q and ends at some point R. The arrow from Q=(x_0,y_0) to R=(x_1,y_1), denoted \overrightarrow{QR}, represents the displacement vector \overrightarrow{QR}=(x_1-x_0,y_1-y_0). For an arrow, we use a bold lower case letter in Roman font, say {\mathbf x}=(a,b) (better for typing) or a lower case letter with an arrow, for example \vec{x}=(a,b) (better for handwriting), to denote the vector {\mathbf x}=\vec{x}=(a,b). Note that the point (a,b) has only one possible drawing, that is, a dot at the location (a,b). By contrast, the vector (a,b) has infinitely many possible drawings: an arrow \overrightarrow{QR} that represents (a,b) can begin at any point in the plane. Another way to say this is that two arrows \overrightarrow{QR}, \overrightarrow{Q'R'} are equal as vectors if R-Q=R'-Q', even though we may have Q\neq Q' and R\neq R'. Many texts make a distinction between points and vectors by using the notation (a,b) for a point and \langle a,b\rangle for a vector. In these notes, we use (a,b) for both the point and the vector.

The ordered pair (0,0) is called the originorigin in \R^2
or the zero vectorzero vector, depending on whether we are thinking of (0,0) as a point or as a vector, respectively. The numbers a,b are called the Cartesian coordinatesCartesian coordinates or the rectangular coordinatesrectangular coordinates of the ordered pair (a,b). The vectors {\mathbf e}_1 = (1,0) and {\mathbf e}_2= (0,1) are called the standard basis vectorsstandard basis vectors in \R^2 {\mathbf e}_1,{\mathbf e}_2
standard basis vectors in \R^2
. We have the following expressions for {\mathbf x}=(a,b) in terms of the standard basis vectors. {\mathbf x} = a{\mathbf e}_1 + b{\mathbf e}_2= ({\mathbf e}_1\cdot {\mathbf x}) {\mathbf e}_1 + ({\mathbf e}_2\cdot {\mathbf x}) {\mathbf e}_2.

section.p:
The normnorm of a vector or modulusmodulus of a vector of an ordered pair (a,b), denoted \left\Vert(a,b)\right\Vert \left\Vert(a,b)\right\Vert
norm of the ordered pair (a,b)
, is defined by \left\Vert(a,b)\right\Vert = \sqrt{(a,b)\cdot (a,b)} = \sqrt{a^2+b^2}. The unit circleunit circle, denoted S^1 S^1
unit circle
, is the set of all ordered pairs in the Cartesian plane with norm equal to one. Geometrically, S^1 is a circle with radius 1, centered at the origin (0,0). S^1 = \{(x,y)\in \R^2\colon x^2+y^2=1\} It is useful to navigate on the unit circle with a single real parameter, where the parameter value 0 corresponds to the point (1,0). A parameter value t\gt 0 corresponds to the point W(t) that lies at the end of a counterclockwise arc along S^1 that begins at (1,0) and has length t. For t\lt 0, the point W(t) lies at the end of a clockwise arc that begins at (1,0) and has length |t|. Another way to say this is that t is the radian measure of the oriented angle \angle SOP, where S=(1,0) and O=(0,0), and P=\wrap(t). The function \wrap\colon \R\to S^1 (often called the wrapping functionwrapping function ) is given by \wrap(t)= (\cos t,\sin t) where t is in radians. Note that \wrap is periodic: the circumference of the unit circle is 2\pi, so we have \wrap(t)=\wrap(t+2\pi k) for every integer k.

statement.p: Draw a figure that illustrates the points P=W(t),S,O, the angle \angle SOP, and the oriented arc from S to P on S^1. Draw one figure for a positive value of t, and draw another figure for a negative value of t.

section.p: Every point P\neq (0,0) is a positive scalar multiple of a unique point \wrap(t) on the unit circle, as follows. Given an arbitrary point P\in \R^2 with P\neq (0,0), let P' be the intersection of the line segment \overline{OP} with the unit circle, so that we have P'=\wrap(t) for some real number t. It is easy to check that P=rP' where r=\left\Vert P\right\Vert. The expression P=r\wrap(t)=(r\cos t,r\sin t) is called the polar form polar form of a vector for P. The numbers r,t are called polar coordinates polar coordinates for P. The number r>0 is the norm of P, and the number t is called (an) argument argument of a vector of P, denoted \arg(P). \arg(r\cos t, r\sin t) = t Because \wrap is periodic with period 2\pi, any number of the form t+2\pi k, for all k\in \Z, is also a value of \arg(P). In this usage, \arg is not technically a function, because it has multiple possible values. A single-valued function may be defined by restricting the value of \arg(P), say, to the range -\pi \lt \arg(P)\leq \pi.

statement.p: Show that "it is easy to check" that P=rP' by checking it.

section.p: Rotations about a point in the plane combine in a simple way: a rotation by t radians, followed by a rotation by s radians, results in a combined rotation by t+s radians. It is useful to encode the composition of rotations in a multiplication operation on S^1. Given points \wrap(t),\wrap(s) on the unit circle, let \wrap(t)\odot \wrap(s) be defined by \wrap(t)\odot \wrap(s) = \wrap(t+s).

statement.p: Let P=(a,b) be a point in \R^2 different from the origin O=(0,0), and let \alpha be a real number. Show that O,P,\alpha P are collinear (that is, show that O,P,\alpha P lie on the same line).

commentary.title: Instructor's solution for
commentary.p: Let P=(r\cos t,r\sin t) be the polar form for P. Then \alpha P = \alpha (r\cos t,r \sin t) = (\alpha r\cos t, \alpha r\sin t) is the polar form for \alpha P. From this it is clear that P,\alpha P have the same argument t. This means that P,\alpha P lie on the same line that passes through the origin and makes an angle of t radians with the positive x-axis.

statement.p: Let P=(a,b) and Q=(c,d) be points in \R^2 such that both P and Q are different from the origin O=(0,0) and Q is not a scalar multiple of P. Let R=P+Q. Show that the points O,P,Q,R are the corners of a parallelogram.

Comment: This result is called the "parallelogram rule for vector addition" because it gives a simple geometric picture: the sum \mathbf{u}+\mathbf{v}=\overrightarrow{OR} of vectors \mathbf{u}=\overrightarrow{OP},\mathbf{v}=\overrightarrow{OQ} is a diagonal of the parallelogram with adjacent sides \overline{OP},\overline{OQ}. Make a sketch!

commentary.title: Instructor's solution for
commentary.p: We must show that the opposite sides \overline{OP} and \overline{QR} are parallel, and also that the opposite sides \overline{OQ} and \overline{PR} are parallel. If a\neq 0, then the sides \overline{OP} and \overline{QR} lie on lines with the same slope b/a, and are therefore parallel. If c\neq 0, then the sides \overline{OQ} and \overline{PR} lie on lines with the slope d/c, and are therefore parallel. If a=0 then the sides \overline{OP} and \overline{QR} are both vertical, and are therefore parallel. Likewise, if c=0, then the sides \overline{OQ} and \overline{PR} are both vertical, and are therefore parallel. It is impossible to have a=c=0, because then Q would be a scalar multiple of P. This takes care of all possible cases, so we conclude that O,P,Q,R form the vertices of a parallelogram.

statement.p:
How do norms and absolute values interact?
Show that \left\Vert r(a,b)\right\Vert=|r|\left\Vert(a,b)\right\Vert for all real numbers r,a,b.
Is it true that |(a,b)\cdot (c,d)|= \left\Vert(a,b)\right\Vert\;\left\Vert(c,d)\right\Vert for all real numbers a,b,c,d? Prove it or give a counterexample.

ol.li: No. Let (a,b)=(1,0) and let (c,d)=(0,1). Then (a,b)\cdot (c,d)=0, so the left side of the equation evaluates to |(1,0)\cdot (0,1)|= 0, while the right side is \left\Vert (1,0)\right\Vert \left\Vert(0,1)\right\Vert = 1\cdot 1 = 1.
Show that \wrap(t)\cdot \wrap(s) = (\wrap(r)\odot \wrap(t))\cdot (\wrap(r)\odot \wrap(s)) for all real numbers r,s,t.
We have W(t)\cdot W(s) = (\cos t, \sin t)\cdot (\cos s,\sin t) = \cos t \cos s + \sin t\sin s =\cos(t-s) where last equality is the formula for the cosine of a difference of angles.

By part a above, the left side is W(t)\cdot W(s)=\cos(t-s). For the right side, we have
(\wrap(r)\odot \wrap(t))\cdot (\wrap(r)\odot \wrap(s))\amp =\wrap(r+t)\cdot \wrap(r+s)\amp \amp (\text{def. of } \odot)
\amp =\cos((r+t)-(r+s))\amp \amp (\text{by part a above}) \amp =\cos(t-s).

statement.p: Write formulas for converting from polar to rectangular coordinates and vice-versa.

commentary.title: Instructor's solution for
commentary.p: To convert from polar to rectangular, use the equations x=r\cos \theta, y=r\sin \theta (show sketches to explain these formulas). To convert from rectangular to polar, use r=\sqrt{x^2+y^2} and \tan \theta = y/x. For the last equation, you must use judgment when x=0 to decide whether \theta should be \pi/2 or -\pi/2. You must also use judgment when calculating \theta = \arctan (y/x). The standard codomain for \arctan is the interval (-\pi/2,\pi/2), so you need to use \theta = \arctan (y/x) + \pi for x\lt 0.

exercise.title: Conventions on linear operations with points and vectors

statement.p:
In these notes, addition and scaling operations are defined for ordered pairs, regardless of whether we view the ordered pairs as points or as vectors. Traditional convention places some restrictions that we have ignored, and will continue to ignore, but nevertheless will present here for the reader's cultural awareness. In short, traditional orthodoxy goes like this:
The operations (a,b)+(c,d) and \alpha(a,b) are allowed when (a,b) and (b,d) are both vectors, and the resulting ordered pairs (a+c,b+d), (\alpha a,\alpha b) are interpreted as vectors.
Addition and scaling of ordered pairs are discouraged, or even banned outright, if the ordered pairs are both points, except for the following two cases:
If P=(a,b) and Q=(c,d) are points, then the operation (c,d)-(a,b) is allowed, and the resulting ordered pair Q-P=(c-a,d-b) is interpreted as a vector, denoted \overrightarrow{PQ}.
If (a,b) is a point and (c,d) is a vector, then the operation (a,b)+(c,d) is allowed, and the resulting ordered pair is interpreted as a point.
Here is a very short summary of the orthodox rules.
vector + vector = vector
point + vector = point
point - point = vector
scalar \cdot vector = vector
point + point = (not recognized)
scalar \cdot point = (not recognized)
The reader will have already noticed that in these notes, we adopt an inclusive approach that allows addition and scaling of points.
